;美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普周五重申承诺公布剩余的相关机密记录约翰·F·肯尼迪总统被刺杀，尽管事实上他在四年任期内有机会这样做时却没有这样做。

;

;“当我回到白宫时，我将解密并解封所有与肯尼迪遇刺有关的文件，”特朗普在他的社交媒体平台Truth Social上写道。

;

;“60年过去了，是时候让美国人民了解真相了！”

;

;美国总统乔·拜登上周表示，国家档案馆已完成对仍属于机密的记录的审查，并建议仍保留一些记录不让公众看到。

;

;“这一行动反映了他的指示，即所有与相关信息有关的信息白宫新闻秘书卡琳·让-皮埃尔 (Karine Jean-Pierre) 在白宫对记者表示：“肯尼迪总统的遇刺事件应该予以公布，除非有最有力的可能理由。”

;

;白宫声明 99% 的记录均已公开此事的公开遭到了肯尼迪暗杀专家的嘲笑，他们批评了 7 月 4 日周末假期前夕的宣布，以及美国政府未能公布全部信息。

;

;“这是一种侮辱。” 《结案：李·哈维·奥斯瓦尔德与刺杀肯尼迪》一书的作者杰拉尔德·波斯纳告诉所有关心此案真相的人，因为拜登白宫故意在基本上是一个长假周末之前的周五晚上发布了它。美国新闻网站 The Messenger。

;

;“没有人不同意所有文件早就应该公布了。这是我们所有人的耻辱。”

;

;不安全、不受欢迎：美国科学家感受到中国倡议的“寒蝉效应”

;

;特朗普周五的声明是在分享《信使报》的文章时发表的报告。该出版物还指出，肯尼迪的侄子、民主党总统候选人小罗伯特·F·肯尼迪也批评拜登政府继续将数千份记录保密。

;

;这位前总统在任职期间也面临着同样的决定。办公室。 2017 年，特朗普监督公布了 19,000 多份文件，但最终违背了完全公布剩余材料的承诺。

;

;特朗普站在 CIA（中央情报局）和 FBI（联邦调查局）一边最终将剩余记录的发布推迟到 2021 年。

;

;据 NBC 新闻当时报道，拜登随后再次将这一过程推迟到 2022 年，届时他又发布了 13,000 份记录。随后，拜登将另一个最后期限定为 2023 年 6 月，这也引发了最近的行动。

;

;肯尼迪遇刺案的新档案被公开

;

;不断涌现的记录让美国政府陷入了困境。 1992 年约翰·F·肯尼迪总统暗杀记录收集法案的精神。国会一致通过的这项法律要求在 2017 年 10 月 26 日之前公开披露所有与暗杀相关的记录。

;

;根据该法律，只有总统才能证实有限数量的国家安全问题，从而证明推迟公开文件的合理性。此后，多位总统都曾利用这一权力推迟公布文件。

;

;大多数研究人员长期以来都否认任何单一文件都是“确凿证据”，会破坏沃伦委员会关于李·哈维·奥斯瓦尔德单独行动的结论。 1963 年 11 月 22 日，他枪杀了肯尼迪。肯尼迪后来在帕克兰医院被宣布死亡。

;上周，法国海军的阿基坦级驱逐舰洛林号访问了法国港口离开日本后的菲律宾。该行程是该舰在该地区长期部署的一部分。此次港口访问恰逢法国亚太武装部队联合司令杰弗鲁瓦·德安迪涅少将访问马尼拉，并会见了外交、国防和军事高级官员。

;

;表明法国作为驻地大国在印太地区发挥更大作用的愿望以及对该地区海域挑战的日益重视。随着印太国家加大军费开支并使其合作伙伴多元化，以应对该地区不断变化的安全形势，巴黎将自己定位为可靠的防务合作伙伴。

;

;洛林号去年才开始服役，是其中之一法国最新的海军舰艇。此次印太之旅是其首次海外航行之一。该驱逐舰四月份参加了法国及其盟国在苏丹的国民撤离行动。上个月，它与美国、日本和加拿大舰艇一起在菲律宾海和南海举行海上演习。

;

;另一艘法国海军舰艇“花型”级护卫舰“草原”号在中国南海进行了一次路过演习3 月，菲律宾海岸警卫队多功能响应船 BRP Capones 出海。草原也在四月穿过台湾海峡。在印度-太平洋其他地方，3月份在孟加拉湾举行的第三次拉彼鲁兹演习中，法国舰艇与美国、澳大利亚、英国、印度和日本同行进行了演习。

;

;4月底和月初5月，南十字军演习五年来首次在南太平洋的法国海外领土新喀里多尼亚举行。今年的演习是该地区规模最大的定期人道主义援助和救灾演习之一，涉及法国、澳大利亚、美国、英国、新西兰、斐济和汤加等 19 个国家。

;

;势头强劲海上行动与空中行动相匹配。作为“Pégase 2023”任务的一部分，法国已派出 19 架飞机参加各种印度-太平洋演习。飞机经停阿联酋法国基地，30小时内飞行11,000多公里，抵达新加坡和马来西亚。

;

;从那里，他们将飞往关岛和帕劳参加比赛参加由美国主导的演习，之后他们将访问韩国、日本和印度尼西亚。返程途中将途经卡塔尔和吉布提。如此长时间的部署展示了法国航空航天平台的能力。

;

;法国在印太地区拥有大量利益，也是最有能力在该地区投射力量的欧洲国家。它在阿联酋和吉布提以及留尼汪岛、马约特岛、新喀里多尼亚和法属波利尼西亚等海外领土设有基地，在该地区拥有8000名士兵和165万法国公民。法国拥有世界第二大专属经济区，面积达1020万平方公里，其中93%位于印太地区。

;

;法国于2019年公布了印太战略。展望未来，可能会增加其部署并向该地区分配更多资源。它可以加强参与小型演习，以增强作战准备，并帮助满足各种地区安全需求。

;

;中国大规模的军事集结以及从台湾海峡到中国南部和东部的一系列热点问题海洋正在推动该地区的国防开支和联合军演激增。中国海军正在获取海外基地的使用权，以支持其蓝水雄心。最近与所罗门群岛达成的一项协议让中国在靠近新喀里多尼亚的南太平洋地区有了立足之地。

;

;法国为何在南海秀肌肉

;

;日益复杂的安全环境为法国国防部门提供了机会。法国可以成为该地区国家的替代武器供应国，以增强其军事能力。例如，巴黎即将达成向印度尼西亚和菲律宾提供鲉鱼级潜艇的交易，此前该国已向印度和马来西亚等其他印太海军提供了同样的潜艇。

;

;去年，印度尼西亚还订购了42 架新型阵风战斗机，第一架将于 2026 年抵达。为了弥补现在与全面交付之间的差距，雅加达从卡塔尔采购了 12 架幻影 2000-5 飞机。印度去年还接收了 36 架“阵风”战机中的最后一批。对于那些摆脱受到严厉制裁的俄罗斯武器但又担心昂贵的美国平台的国家来说，法国可以成为一个选择。

;

;与菲律宾的潜艇计划将会很大。菲律宾缺乏地下能力，使其成为第一岛链中的异类。这对于一个海洋和群岛国家来说是一个巨大的讽刺，但该国签署潜艇合同的努力却因Covid-19大流行而泡汤。随着马尼拉经济的复苏，法国在新马科斯政府的领导下重新启动了竞标。

;

;过去的交易为这次改变游戏规则的收购提供了基础。法国于2018年和2019年向菲律宾海岸警卫队交付了快速巡逻艇和一艘近海巡逻船。2021年，法国首次参加了菲美双边海上演习“Sama-Sama”。上个月，法国总统马克龙再次邀请菲律宾总统小费迪南德·马科斯对巴黎进行国事访问。无论此次访问能否达成协议，法国在印太地区的进军都在全力推进。

;美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦将于周六在北京会见女性经济学家，以期在与以男性为主的中国政府领导人会面后，人们开始关注性别多样性。

;

;耶伦是第一位担任美国财政部长的女性，她将女性对经济的贡献和重要性作为其任期的焦点，经常与女性经济学家和女性会面。一位财政部高级官员表示，与中国经济学家共进午餐将为耶伦带来好处，她也是首位担任美国财政部长的女性美联储，一个“与正常政策结构之外的一些人互动”的机会。财政部没有透露参与其中的女性的名字。

;

;中国国家主席习近平担任党总书记的十年间，参与政治和担任高级政府职务的女性人数有所下降，劳动力中的性别差距不断扩大。政府强调妇女更传统的角色。

;

;联合国六月份的一份报告敦促中国采用法定配额和性别平等制度，以提高妇女在政府中的代表性。

;

;联合国委员会关于消除对妇女歧视的调查发现，第十四届全国人民代表大会代表中，女性比例略高于26%，自10月以来，在由24名委员组成的中国共产党政治局中，女性没有代表，这是20年来的首次。

;

;目前，中国最高的女性政治家是沉益勤，她于三月被任命为中国五位国务委员之一。她的级别高于部长，负责监督社会福利、退伍军人事务和体育。

;

;相比之下，耶伦是美国总统乔·拜登内阁 25 名成员中的 13 名女性之一，该内阁是美国性别最多元化的内阁

;

;在不确定性的阴云下，中国以彩虹迎接美国财政部长

;

;目前占据美国参议院四分之一的席位和美国众议院28.7%的席位根据罗格斯大学女性政治中心的数据，女性在女性政治中的比例也很高。

;

;最近的一项研究显示，中国在行业高层中的女性代表性方面也落后。

;

;贝恩公司领导力咨询公司史宾沙 (Spencer Stuart) 在 3 月份报告称，女性在企业高管中仅占 19%，而领先国家的平均比例为 25%。

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 02:20:02 +0800 Global space race and orbital debris drive need for global arbitrationhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3226625/global-space-race-and-orbital-debris-drive-need-global-arbitration?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.08 01:00;

;我们正在看到一场新的太空竞赛，中国和美国正在领先-领导多项重要任务。 《赢得太空：美国如何保持超级大国地位》一书的作者布兰登·韦彻特表示，“我敢说，中国在太空领域的几个关键指标上已经赶上了美国。事实上，在我认为一个国家太空计划最重要的方面——载人航天计划——中国已经超越了美国。”

;

;这是在中国初创企业太空先锋最近推出的情况下进行的。由煤基航空煤油提供动力的火箭。这被誉为中国航天事业的一项重要突破，是一种高效、可持续的能源形式。

;

;鉴于地球上的人们目前面临的所有挑战，人们想知道为什么太空是可以理解的对某些人来说这是一个优先事项。到达那里既困难又昂贵，如果没有特殊设备，人类就无法生存，卫星和机器人在其中运行甚至存在风险。

;

;然而，尽管存在所有风险，太空仍然提供了了解生命的宝贵机会地球上的优势以及某些类型的盈利业务在地面上无法复制的优势。

;

;太空也是安全和国防的舞台。然而，太空作业面临的问题越来越多，特别是与碎片和碰撞有关的问题，太空中发生严重事故并造成重大经济损失的可能性越来越大。这值得进一步关注。

;

;轨道上发生大规模碰撞的可能性正在增加，特别是考虑到绕地球运行的空间碎片数量巨大。例如，国际空间站去年不得不转向，以避免俄罗斯反卫星武器试验产生的空间碎片。随着太空变得越来越繁忙，争议在所难免，但责任在哪里呢？你能拥有自己的空间吗？如何解决争端？

;

;太空的一些独特元素和管理该环境的法律将其与其他领域区分开来。例如，1967年的《外层空间条约》规定，任何国家都不能宣布对太空和天体的主权。在太空中实际执行国际规则的困难、对“外太空”从哪里开始缺乏明确的定义以及各国是否对其公民在太空中的活动承担全部责任的明确性也使其独一无二。

;

;关于国家或私人实体如何以及在何种程度上对轨道碰撞和空间碎片承担责任，存在一些不确定性。这是一个敏感话题，因为人造太空物体可以在轨道上停留很多年。

;

;管理太空的大部分法律都源于冷战时期。这套国际太空条约是在 20 世纪 60 年代和 1970 年代人类太空活动的早期阶段谈判和批准的，它们反映了起草者对政府而非太空商业用途的关注。尽管私人使用太空可能是可以预见的，但这些条约并没有谈到这个问题。

;

;就太空碰撞而言，1972 年《太空责任公约》规定，一个发射国可能对另一个发射国承担责任如果发生在轨碰撞，则取决于责任方。坠落地球并对另一个国家或其人民造成损害的物体，发射国应承担严格责任。

;

;我们应该担心中国火箭撞击地球的空间碎片吗？

;

;公约进一步规定，如果索赔未能得到解决，最终将由索赔委员会进行仲裁。因此，它对太空碰撞责任的一般原则做了很多规定——例如，过错方应支付损害赔偿金——但未能规定解决争端的制度。

;

;随着太空碰撞事故的大幅增加，在商业卫星流量近几十年中，这种差距尤为严重。它假设所有争议都将在政府对政府层面上解决，但这一假设在实践中可能不具有商业可行性。简而言之，目前涉及太空碰撞的私人索赔尚无既定框架。

;

;我们不需要重新发明轮子来解决太空争端。仲裁广泛应用于跨境案件以及私人当事人与外国政府实体之间的案件，具有多种特质，使其成为解决此类争议的有效方式。仲裁员可以根据其特定的技术或行业经验来指定。机构可以利用其庞大的网络来确定针对每个争议量身定制的专家。

;

;此外，仲裁程序通常是私人且保密的，可以提供更好的环境来处理争议的机密或专有信息。通常与高科技航天器相关的那种。通过适当的保障措施，仲裁甚至可以处理机密信息。

;

;虽然可以在现有国际法律体系内实现对太空相关争议进行具有约束力的仲裁的可行制度，但要使仲裁具有约束力需要采取多项举措开始。首先，公司和政府之间必须就同意将争议提交国际仲裁的好处以及构成该过程一部分的国际规则和程序的类型达成共识。接下来，需要就提交此类争议的机制达成一致。

;

;可行的仲裁系统将是有益的。主要航天国家可以在其许可程序中采用这一选项来解决未来的争端，特别是当涉及私营企业时。

;

;我们很幸运，在轨碰撞相对较少，而且已经发生过并没有导致旷日持久的纠纷。然而，发生此类事件的可能性与日俱增，人为制造碎片的风险也与日俱增。这些事件提醒我们，太空中仍然存在潜在的真正争端，以及寻找主动解决方案的真正好处。

;欧盟官员正忙于绘制欧盟对中国锗和镓供应的暴露情况，此前北京表示将从 8 月 1 日起限制其出口。

;中国商务部周一下令对这两种关键技术元素及其几种化合物实施出口限制，以报复西方的新限制措施其半导体行业以国家安全问题为由。

;

;周四在布鲁塞尔与贸易外交官举行的会议上，欧盟委员会官员参与讨论的人士表示，他们对中国报复的规模感到“害怕”。中国以国家安全为由的说法让他们感到惊慌，担心这些限制可能会扩大到其他关键矿产。

;

;;

;“It could not have been a warmer reception than what we received,” said American businessman Jeff Bowman after spending a week in China last month.

;

;Bowman is the CEO of the US materials science company Cocona, with his unique sweat-drying Masterbatch additive for yarn garnering significant interest in the China-based fabric sector.

;

;“The reception couldn't have been more cordial – super excited to see us, wanting to do business with us,” said Bowman, speaking from his home in the US state of Oregon.

;

;He has set up a wholly foreign-owned enterprise in China, with one client even agreeing a deal during the recent visit.

;

;Around half of Cocona's Masterbatch is shipped to Chinese yarn spinners, with roughly 20 per cent of its US$10 million to US$20 million annual company revenues plus mill business coming from China - a share that is only expected to grow.

;

;Bowman's story is bellwether for American industry – a pile-up of obstacles notwithstanding.

;

;First came the US-China trade war in 2018, then Washington's curbs on technology transfers, later the coronavirus lockdowns of 2022, and all along US calls for decoupling supply chains away amid deepening political rifts.

;

;“The typical sentiment is we wish the governments would get out of the way and let businesses do their thing,” Bowman added.

;

;American industries as diverse as film, nuts, dairy and hi-tech equipment are also circling back to China with intent to grow business again despite, in many cases, a decline at the start of the US-China trade and tech wars.

;

;They are making it in some cases by selling to super-rich clients who can absorb price increases caused by the trade tariff increases.

;

;Others have found that China needs US imports because it cannot produce enough domestically, while tech firms in the iconic Silicon Valley have started re-exploring the market because of its sheer size.

;

;China's post-coronavirus reopening since December particularly prompted US companies to re-explore the world's second-largest economy, with entrepreneurs such as Bowman now able to resume in-person visits.

;

;“I've been criss-crossing the [US] for the last 18 months or so, and found that it's not entirely true that everyone in America agrees that we can't work with China,” said Ker Gibbs, the former American Chamber of Commerce Shanghai president, who is now executive-in-residence at the University of San Francisco, in mid-June.

;

;“People are definitely sensing that there's a problem, but Americans and Chinese are not natural enemies. On the contrary, we share a lot of the same values, especially when it comes to business.”

;

;California's agriculture sector saw a 30 per cent drop in its China business at the start of the trade dispute, but income has edged up since 2018, said William Matthews, a researcher with the University of California Agricultural Issues Centre.

;

;He pointed to demand from wealthy Chinese consumers, plus lack of available land in China to grow enough food for its population.

;

;Consumers in China buy around half of the state's annual US$2 billion pistachio and almond crop, he said.

;

;California is the biggest US dairy producer and Chinese importers are buying what would otherwise be a “glut” for the state itself, Matthews added.

;

;“China has been moving up,” Matthews said, pointing particularly to dairy and nuts. “Incomes have been going up pretty steadily over the past 30 to 40 years and the number one thing they want to do is improve their diets.

;

;“[Growers in the state] might squawk a bit at the tariffs, but when it comes down to it, California is very competitive in producing quality products at a low cost.”

;

;Former US president Donald Trump started the trade war because of what he saw as “unfair” practices by China, including limited market access, intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers.

;

;The dispute has raised tariffs on US$550 billion worth of goods from both sides.

;

;But 59 per cent of American Chamber of Commerce in China respondents told a survey in April that they had a positive outlook on the recovery of the Chinese economy, up from 33 per cent in a survey conducted in October, November and February.

;

;In 2021, China cut the number of American studio films allowed for release by a third against the backdrop of political tension.

;

;And in December, the US government decided to curb its cooperation with American studios that edit films for Chinese censors.

;

;Was the US-China phase-one trade deal a 'historic failure', and what's next?

;

;Director, screenwriter and actor Derek Ting of New York is hardly deterred. He filmed the 2016 movie Always in China and would do it again.

;

;He filmed at a hospital venue in Guangzhou and recalls hiring “talented” and “hardworking” local fixers.

;

;The streamed movie has racked up millions of views in China, he added.

;

;The Chinese market has more promise with the rise of streaming, Ting believes, since online films do not fall under the curbs on foreign studio releases.

;

;Chinese cinemas, he added, are recovering from coronavirus-era closures.

;

;“I think everyone would say it's a huge market,” Ting said. “If you have something right for it, and they want it, then why not?”

;

;Silicon Valley firms see investing in China as “more harried” now than pre-2019, said Danny Levinson, the US-based former technology head of a China-focused venture capital fund.

;

;He pointed to the pullback in Chinese firms seeking initial public offerings in the US, a “crackdown” on foreign data firms in China, and the localisation of Silicon Valley venture capital firm Sequoia Capital's China investments.

;

;The two sides “may be in the midst of a longer period of separation”, Levinson said.

;

;US-China trade war timeline of key dates and events since July 2018

;

;But many still want to expand in China now because it is “simply too big a market to ignore”, said Mark Natkin, managing director with the Beijing-based market research firm Marbridge Consulting.

;

;“After a tough three years of zero-Covid, China's policymakers – particularly local governments – are still very eager to attract more foreign direct investment,” he added.

;

;Now US enterprises worry that Chinese industries will eventually outcompete American exporters, analysts said.

;

;“For those which have already been hammering away at it for the last 10 to 20 years, selling their China operations to a local buyer in return for a big bundle of cash is often a welcome alternative to simply grinding on in an increasingly competitive environment,” Natkin said.

;

;“China now has a lot more home-grown companies with the resources to make such acquisitions.”

;

;Chinese farmers are trying to grow some of California's signature crops, Matthews said, while growers in California must combat an erratic water supply to stay competitive.

;

;“Market access barriers in manufacturing in China have merely moved up the value chain,” said Derek Scissors, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute public policy think tank.

;

;“The problem remains that China wants foreign production only until it can replace foreign production with its own. It's win-win, until China doesn't need you any more.”

;Hong Kong should wait until spring to introduce a waste-charging scheme as the city does not have enough sanitation workers to handle an expected peak in demand over the Christmas and Lunar New Year holidays, an industry group has said.

;

;Authorities plan to introduce an 11 HK cent charge for government-designated garbage bags at the end of the year, after the Legislative Council passed an amendment to the Waste Disposal Ordinance in 2021.

;

;The Environmental Services Contractors Alliance on Friday said it did not have the manpower or time to prepare for the scheme's intended launch in December.

;

;“The government has not publicised or educated the public on any specific implementation models regarding garbage collection since the legislation passed in 2021,” the group said. “If the government insists on implementing it by the end of 2023, we are afraid we will be unable to cooperate, thus creating confusion.”

;The alliance represents seven business groups and about 200 companies, which cover services such as recycling and pest control.

;The amount of garbage would “increase exponentially” during the winter holiday season, while the Lunar New Year break would create a manpower crunch as more than 30 per cent of sanitation workers would be on leave, the industry group said.

;

;“It would be mission impossible for the industry to recruit additional manpower to handle work related to the garbage levy during this period,” it said.

;

;The levy is part of a raft of measures proposed by environmental authorities to help reduce the amount of waste generated by households.

;

;In 2021, the city handled 4.15 million tonnes of municipal solid waste, 70 per cent of which was sent to landfills.

;

;Secretary for Environment and Ecology Tse Chin-wan has repeatedly said authorities were confident the scheme could be rolled out by the end of 2023. The city had already announced an 18-month transition period to prepare the way.

;

;A source familiar with the situation said the Legislative Council had not set a definitive launch date for the government to follow.

;

;Alliance spokesman Raymond Yau Pui-lam said the industry would have to learn a new waste management model, which would take time. “At least we should wait until April when people return to work,” he added.

;

;The government has already faced some setbacks ahead of the launch, such as the Environmental Protection Department last November withdrawing the tender for the new bags after the suggested prices were “far beyond” the government's expectations. A retender was later launched in March and ended two months later.

;Hong Kong must tackle plastic pollution at source, not look to dubious fixes

;A spokeswoman on Friday said the department had received 45 bids during the retender.

;“We have completed the preliminary tender review and will submit the tender review report to the relevant department for final approval,” she said. “We expect to award all contracts in July or August 2023, with a view to starting the production of designated bags and designated labels in the third quarter of this year.

;

;“To ensure that the designated bag has sufficient storage capacity to meet the demand, we have required the designated bag manufacturer and logistics contractor to have sufficient capacity to meet the additional demand in the contract.”

;Legco's environmental affairs panel is also expected to discuss the scheme next Friday, with officials expected to explain how it will be introduced.

;The world recorded its hottest day ever on Thursday, breaking previous highs set on Monday and Tuesday as global average temperatures continue to climb, according to data from the US National Centres on Environmental Prediction.

;

;The global average temperature hit 17.23 degrees Celsius (63.01° degrees Fahrenheit) on Thursday, according to the government agency.

;

;The record comes days after intense heatwaves in the United States and China, while another killed more than 100 people in Mexico, as temperatures soar globally.

;

;Jingxing checked in almost 43.3°C (110°F), while the merely unusually warm, like Antarctica, showed temperatures across the continent were as much as 8 degrees Fahrenheit (4.5°C) above normal this week.

;

;The temperature is ramping up across Europe this week, too. Germany's weather agency, DWD, has predicted highs of 37°C (99°F) on Sunday and the Health Ministry has issued a warning to vulnerable people.

;

;World swelters to unofficial hottest day ever Monday then gets hotter Tuesday

;

;On Thursday, the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service said June was the hottest month ever, smashing the previous June record in 2019 by a substantial margin.

;

;“Such records are the predictable consequence of a short-term El Niño temperature boost coming on top of the long-term global warming trend due to mankind's greenhouse gas emissions,” said Robert Rohde, lead scientist for climate science non-profit Berkeley Earth, on Twitter.

;

;The El Nino weather pattern emerged this year, bringing warm sea surface temperatures in the eastern and central Pacific Ocean.

;

;After the previous daily high from August 2016 was first broken on Monday, several scientists predicted more record-setting days this year.

;

;“Expect many more hottest days in the future,” said Saleemul Huq, director of Bangladesh's International Centre for Climate Change and Development, in a statement.

;

;Robert Watson, a scientist and former chairman of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said governments and the private sector “are not truly committed to address climate change.” Nor are citizens, he said.

;

;“They demand cheap energy, cheap food and do not want to pay the true cost of food and energy,” Watson said.

;

;;2023.07.07 23:00;
;;

;Competition between the United States and China is not a “winner-take-all” scenario, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said on Friday as the world's two largest economies signalled that further talks may be in the pipeline amid a growing rift over a range of issues, including trade, technology and Taiwan.

;

;“We seek healthy economic competition that is not winner-take-all, but that, with a fair set of rules, can benefit both countries over time,” Yellen said during a meeting with Premier Li Qiang on Friday. “The United States will, in certain circumstances, need to pursue targeted actions to protect its national security, and we may disagree [with China] in these instances.

;

;“However, we should not allow any disagreement to lead to misunderstandings that unnecessarily worsen our bilateral economic and financial relationship.”

;

;Yellen added that she hoped her visit to China could “spur more regular channels of communication” between the two countries, despite their disagreements.

;

;Li told Yellen in Beijing that whether China and the US have the “right” relations is relevant to the future of mankind, party mouthpiece CCTV said on Friday evening.

;

;And Li reportedly reminded Yellen that presidents Xi Jinping and Joe Biden reached a consensus in Bali last year, regarding the importance of mutual respect and win-win cooperation.

;

;“It is hoped that the US side will take a practical and sensible approach and work with China to get China-US relations back on the right track,” Li was quoted by CCTV as saying. “Strengthening cooperation is a real need and the right choice.

;

;“Both sides should have candid communication on important economic and related issues and seek a consensus, injecting positive energy and stability into China-US economic relations.”

;

;China's Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Friday also called Yellen's visit a “concrete measure to implement the important consensus” after the presidents' November meeting in Indonesia.

;

;The ministry added that her visit would also “strengthen communication and exchanges between the two countries in the financial field”.

;

;China hopes the US will take “concrete action” to create a favourable environment for the healthy development of bilateral economic and trade ties, according to the MOF statement.

;

;Economic and trade relations are mutually beneficial and win-win, and there is no winner in a trade war and “decoupling”, the ministry said.

;

;Earlier on Friday, Yellen met with American businesses in Beijing and told the American Chamber of Commerce in China that a “stable and constructive relationship between the US and China is in the interests of American workers and businesses”.

;

;“I have been particularly troubled by punitive actions that have been taken against US firms in recent months,” Yellen said.

;

;“I am also concerned about new export controls recently announced by China on two critical minerals used in technologies like semiconductors, we are still evaluating the impact of these actions. It reminds us of the importance of building resilient and diversified supply chains.

;

;“I have made clear that the US does not seek a wholesale separation in our economies. We seek to diversify and not to decouple. A decoupling of the world's two largest economies would be destabilising for the global economy, and it will be virtually impossible to undertake.”

;

;Yellen also called for a shift to market reforms in China, and highlighted US concerns over China's use of “non-market” tools that include subsidies for state-owned enterprises and domestic firms, along with barriers to market access for foreign firms.

;

;US restrictions on China's access to chip technology are designed to be “narrowly targeted”, are based on “straightforward national security considerations”, and are not intended to gain an economic advantage over China, Yellen added.

;

;Yellen also met with central bank governor Yi Gang and former economic tsar Liu He on Friday, according to a report by Reuters, citing an unnamed US Treasury official.

;

;The Post reported last month that former vice-premier Liu was still being regularly consulted on important financial and economic affairs – particularly on issues related to the US.

;

;Yellen is the most senior US official to visit Beijing following Secretary of State Antony Blinken's fence-mending trip in June, when he met Xi and senior diplomats, including Foreign Minister Qin Gang and Wang Yi, director of the Office of the Central Commission for Foreign Affairs.

;

;It has also been reported that US climate change envoy John Kerry will visit China next week, while expectations are high for US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo to meet her counterparts in Beijing.

;

;The primary objective of Yellen's four-day visit to China, which started on Thursday, is to ease tensions between the two sides, although expectations are low that it will result in the resolution of many differences.

;

;Ahead of Yellen's trip, China stepped up its response to US chip curbs by launching new export controls on two metals key to semiconductor manufacturing.

;

;What to expect from US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's trip to China

;

;In May, China also banned US chip giant Micron Technology from selling its chips to key infrastructure projects, citing national security risks.

;

;And in March, Chinese authorities raided the office of US corporate due diligence firm Mintz Group in Beijing and detained five local staff.

;

;Xi and Biden had agreed to hold further discussions to stabilise China-US relations during their meeting at the G20 summit in Bali.

;

;But relations soured again in February after Washington accused Beijing of operating a spy balloon over sensitive locations housing nuclear weapons in Montana.

;

;China denied the allegations, saying that it was a “civilian airship” that had deviated from its planned route.

;

;The balloon was later shot down by a US fighter jet, but the dispute caused Blinken to postpone his visit to China until last month.
